answer_html: \(F=\frac{1960}{3}N.\) This is the hydrostatic force on each of the triangular sides.
answer_latex: $F=\frac{1960}{3}N.$ This is the hydrostatic force on each of the triangular sides.
hints_html:
Recall that hydrostatic pressure is given by,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}P=\rho{g}h\end{aligned}\]

where \(\rho\) is the density of water, g, the gravitational constant, and h the height from the top.

It is important that height is measured from the top of the surface because as depth increases, there is more water above you, increasing to the pressure.

Recall that they hydrostatic force on an object of area A at height h is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}F=\rho{g}hA\end{aligned}\]

where \(\rho\) is the density of the surrounding liquid.

Recall that hydrostatic pressure is given by,

:<math>
\displaystyle{}P=\rho{g}h
</math>

where <math>\rho</math> is the density of water, g, the gravitational constant, and h the height from the top.

It is important that height is measured from the top of the surface because as depth increases, there is more water above you, increasing to the pressure.
Recall that they hydrostatic force on an object of area A at height h is

:<math>
\displaystyle{}F=\rho{g}hA
</math>

where <math>\rho</math> is the density of the surrounding liquid.
question: 7 (a)
sols_html:
Hydrostatic Force was not covered in the 2012 offering of this course. Time might better be spent solving other problems given how soon the exam is coming.

Consider the triangular side pictured to the right 300pxthumbnailright. It has height 2 and length 1. Also consider a little rectangular sliver in the picture of length L(y) and height dy. The reason we consider rectangular pieces with constant height is because the pressure depends on height and so we would like the effect from height to be the same on any given rectangular piece. We will use the labelling in the diagram with the bottom vertex being (0,0), the right vertex being (1/2,2) and the left vertex being (-1/2,2). With our origin at the bottom, we will label y from there. This means that the height (as measured from the top of the surface) is (2-y). We then have that the force on any given rectangle, dF, is,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}dF=\rho{g}(2-y)L(y)\textrm{d}y.\end{aligned}\]

We could then get the total force by integrating dF but first we need an expression for the length in terms of the height, y. The length of any rectangle will start at the left edge of the triangle and end at the right edge. We can use the coordinates that we listed to find equations for these lines. The right edge is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=4x\end{aligned}\]

which written in terms of y is,

\[\begin{aligned} x_R=\frac{y}{4}\end{aligned}\]

where we have added a subscript R to indicate it’s the right edge. Notice we compute the line by finding the slope using the right vertex and bottom vertex and then notice that the line goes through our origin to its y-intercept is zero. We can similarly get that the left edge is

\[\begin{aligned} x_L=-\frac{y}{4}.\end{aligned}\]

This can also be argued with symmetry of the right edge. We then have that

\[\begin{aligned} L(y)=x_R-x_L=\frac{y}{4}-\left(-\frac{y}{4}\right)=\frac{y}{2}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we can now get F via integration where we see that y starts at zero and ends at y=2. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} F=\int_0^2\rho{g}(2-y)L(y)\textrm{d}y=\int_0^2\rho{g}\frac{2y-y^2}{2}\textrm{d}y=\rho{g}\left.\left(\frac{y^2}{2}-\frac{y^3}{6}\right)\right|_0^2=\frac{2\rho{g}}{3}.\end{aligned}\]

We are told in the problem that the density is 1000kg/m^3 and we take the gravitational constant as 9.8N/kg. Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} F=\frac{2}{3}980=\frac{1960}{3}N.\end{aligned}\]

This is the hydrostatic force on each of the triangular sides.
sols_raw:
''Hydrostatic Force was not covered in the 2012 offering of this course. Time might better be spent solving other problems given how soon the exam is coming.''


Consider the triangular side pictured to the right [[file:Math101Apr20097a.png|300px|thumbnail|right]].  It has height 2 and length 1.  Also consider a little rectangular sliver in the picture of length L(y) and height dy.  The reason we consider rectangular pieces with constant height is because the pressure depends on height and so we would like the effect from height to be the same on any given rectangular piece.  We will use the labelling in the diagram with the bottom vertex being (0,0), the right vertex being (1/2,2) and the left vertex being (-1/2,2).  With our origin at the bottom, we will label y from there.  This means that the height (as measured from the top of the surface) is (2-y).  We then have that the force on any given rectangle, dF, is,

:<math>
\displaystyle{}dF=\rho{g}(2-y)L(y)\textrm{d}y.
</math>

We could then get the total force by integrating dF but first we need an expression for the length in terms of the height, y.  The length of any rectangle will start at the left edge of the triangle and end at the right edge.  We can use the coordinates that we listed to find equations for these lines.  The right edge is given by

:<math>
\displaystyle y=4x
</math>

which written in terms of y is,

:<math>
x_R=\frac{y}{4}
</math>

where we have added a subscript R to indicate it's the right edge.  Notice we compute the line by finding the slope using the right vertex and bottom vertex and then notice that the line goes through our origin to its y-intercept is zero.  We can similarly get that the left edge is

:<math>
x_L=-\frac{y}{4}.
</math>

This can also be argued with symmetry of the right edge.  We then have that

:<math>
L(y)=x_R-x_L=\frac{y}{4}-\left(-\frac{y}{4}\right)=\frac{y}{2}.
</math>

Therefore we can now get F via integration where we see that y starts at zero and ends at y=2.  Therefore,

:<math>
F=\int_0^2\rho{g}(2-y)L(y)\textrm{d}y=\int_0^2\rho{g}\frac{2y-y^2}{2}\textrm{d}y=\rho{g}\left.\left(\frac{y^2}{2}-\frac{y^3}{6}\right)\right|_0^2=\frac{2\rho{g}}{3}.
</math>

We are told in the problem that the density is 1000kg/m^3 and we take the gravitational constant as 9.8N/kg.  Therefore,

:<math>
F=\frac{2}{3}980=\frac{1960}{3}N.
</math>

This is the hydrostatic force on each of the triangular sides.
statement_html:
An open metal tank has two ends which are isosceles triangles with vertex at the bottom, two sides which are rectangular, and an open top. The tank is 1 metre wide, 2 metres deep, 10 metres long and full of water (density = 1000 kg/m3).

(a) What is the hydrostatic force on each triangular end?
statement_latex:
An open metal tank has two ends which are isosceles triangles with
vertex at the bottom, two sides which are rectangular, and an open top.
The tank is 1 metre wide, 2 metres deep, 10 metres long and full of
water (\emph{density = 1000 kg/m\textsuperscript{3}}).

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
(a) What is the hydrostatic force on each triangular end?
\end{description}
statement_raw:
An open metal tank has two ends which are isosceles triangles with vertex at the bottom, two sides which are rectangular, and an open top. The tank is 1 metre wide, 2 metres deep, 10 metres long and full of water (''density = 1000 kg/m<sup>3</sup>'').

:(a) What is the hydrostatic force on each triangular end?
